
A rookie hacker used RSA but chose both primes as Blum integers. Can you recover their secret from 2280536842871682811214830374244861099429228564079107295111050230254167999874549628952084445230818611293402124229192211005970948820181407328100706683161524 before they patch their keys?


The flag format is flag{...}
n=7170421470510867746498471124577861147193387962667072704807963472354206731729778374428250332789559363151930526669169839271771333434724314761840516176772669, e=3942364729888759214386724640104388271153320530290436468213787374255942854487046314257477505487923469255695788291583355248410867446140519936727188429577689
The lower 104 bits of p are: 71569116487898531996120563471805772767


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{usujicn5}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 2280536842871682811214830374244861099429228564079107295111050230254167999874549628952084445230818611293402124229192211005970948820181407328100706683161524
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=7170421470510867746498471124577861147193387962667072704807963472354206731729778374428250332789559363151930526669169839271771333434724314761840516176772669, e=3942364729888759214386724640104388271153320530290436468213787374255942854487046314257477505487923469255695788291583355248410867446140519936727188429577689
The lower 104 bits of p are: 71569116487898531996120563471805772767

extra_info: p=83537530645564497859394916457960404463636448448159749746657474024778947818463, q=85834730989760084314173027087164156089739309409047168737090689797604493406563, Ï†(n)=7170421470510867746498471124577861147193387962667072704807963472354206731729609002166615008207385795208385402108616463513914126516240566598018132735547644
subtype: blum_integers
archetype: rsa
